body_content.explanation: to (cause to) turn around and around, especially fast:
examples: The earth spins on its axis.
The roulette players silently watched the wheel spin around/round.
He was killed when his car hit a tree and spun off the road.
Spin the ball (= make it turn around and around as you throw it) and it will change direction when it hits the ground.

body_content.explanation: If your head or the room spins, you feel as if it is turning around and around, and you cannot balance:
examples: The room started spinning and I felt faint.

body_content.explanation: to make thread by twisting fibres , or to produce something using thread:
examples: The final stage of the production of cotton is when it is spun into thread.

body_content.explanation: to tell a story, either to deceive someone or for entertainment:
examples: He spun some tale about needing to take time off work because his mother was ill.

body_content.explanation: (of a vehicle) to move quickly, or to move quickly in a vehicle:
examples: We were spinning along, when suddenly one of our tyres burst.
Chris spun past in a flashy new car.

body_content.explanation: the movement of something turning round very quickly:
examples: I hit something on the road, which sent the car into a spin.
Suddenly, the plane went into a spin.
These clothes need another spin (= to be turned round very fast in a machine to get water out of them) - they're still very wet.
She put a lot of spin on the ball (= threw or hit it in a way that made it spin).

body_content.explanation: a way of describing an idea or situation that makes it seem better than it really is, especially in politics:
examples: They have tried to put a positive spin on the situation.
This report puts a different spin on the issue.

body_content.explanation: a short journey in a car for pleasure:
examples: Rupert took me for a spin in his new car.
